subject: history
title: Surat Split of Indian National Congress (1907)
description: Division of Congress into Moderates and Extremists factions at Surat session

introContext.title: Background to Split
introContext.description: Growing differences between old and new leaders of Congress
introContext.timeline: Tensions building since Bengal Partition (1905); culminated at Surat (1907)
introContext.trigger: Swadeshi Movement showed effectiveness of aggressive methods; moderates uncomfortable

context.previousSession: Calcutta (1906) - both factions cooperated; adopted Swaraj, Swadeshi, Boycott, National Education
context.tension: Moderates regretted radical resolutions; wanted to reverse
context.presidency: Dispute over who should be President for Surat session

controversies.outcome: Moderates prevailed; Rash Behari Ghosh made President

controversies.moderates: Wanted to amend constitution to restrict radical methods
Wanted to dilute radical resolutions of Calcutta session

description: Tilak rose to speak; moderates opposed
aftermath: Moderates held separate session, elected Rash Behari Ghosh
Moderates retained control of official Congress organization

reunification.outcome: Congress reunited; extremists' methods gained acceptance

historicalSignificance.title: Historical Significance & Assessment
negativeImpact: Weakened nationalist movement at crucial time
positiveAspect: Prepared ground for Gandhi's mass movements
After reunion (1916), Congress adopted more radical program
lessons: Purely constitutional methods inadequate against colonial power
